header_summary:
The Bitcoin Foundation's proposal addresses the pressing need for Bitcoin to transition to quantum-resistant cryptography due to the potential threat posed by advancements in quantum computing, such as Google's trapped-ion quantum computer. It outlines a phased strategy for integrating quantum-resistant (QR) witness programs, gradually phasing out classical ECDSA outputs, and ultimately freezing classical UTXOs to prevent quantum-enabled thefts. The proposal also highlights the selection of SPHINCS+-SHAKE256f for its robust quantum-resistant properties, requiring updates from hardware wallets, exchanges, and miners to adapt to these new protocols ([source](https://gnusha.org/pi/bitcoindev/4d6ecde7-e959-4e6c-a0aa-867af8577151n@googlegroups.com/T/#u#m6b17340df61fb954ca24db75d171aa8d665e6e67)).

James Tagg introduces the Quantum Secure Asset Verification & Escrow (QSAVE) initiative as a novel approach for protecting Bitcoin from quantum attacks, focusing on safeguarding coins through a non-sovereign wealth fund model. This proposal aims to preserve the full principal amount of vulnerable Bitcoins and utilize the returns for global public welfare, offering a balanced alternative to drastic measures against quantum threats. It includes a detailed recovery process, consensus layer strategies, and a governance structure involving cryptographic proof and government-issued identification for ownership verification ([source](https://gnusha.org/pi/bitcoindev/SN6PR12MB2735280A252DD62231D1320AA523A@SN6PR12MB2735.namprd12.prod.outlook.com/T/#u#m4d200793abb1fcfa0608e2e4af53db1145b112d7)).

In the realm of blockchain security and efficiency, zawy's discussion introduces a formula for calculating work in Proof of Work (PoW) systems, emphasizing the importance of retaining a significant number of block headers for accuracy. This formula and the discussion on Proofs of Proof-of-Work (PoPoW) schemes suggest scalability mechanisms for managing header storage efficiently as blockchain height increases. Meanwhile, jdlcdl presents significant advancements in the KEF Encryption Format, enhancing the encryption of bip39 mnemonics for secure storage across various mediums, highlighting community feedback's role in refining these specifications ([source](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/correcting-the-error-in-getnetworkhashrateps/1745/22), [krux release 23.09.0](https://github.com/selfcustody/krux/releases/tag/v23.09.0)).

recent_posts.title: [Draft BIP] Quantum-Resistant Transition Framework for Bitcoin
recent_posts.summary:
- The proposal addresses Bitcoin's transition to quantum-resistant cryptography to safeguard against quantum threats.
- It outlines a phased strategy starting with soft-fork QR witness programs to prevent quantum-assisted theft.
- SPHINCS+-SHAKE256f is selected for its superior security against quantum decryption algorithms.

recent_posts.title: [BIP Proposal] No burn, Quantum Migration Proposal, Quantum Secure Asset Verification & Escrow (QSAVE)
recent_posts.summary:
- The QSAVE proposal offers protection for Bitcoins against quantum computing threats.
- It aims to secure at-risk coins while supporting global welfare through generated returns.
- The project proposes a detailed strategy for asset recovery and consensus building.

recent_posts.title: Correcting the error in getnetworkhashrateps
recent_posts.summary:
- The formula $W = \text{S} \times \frac{2^{256}}{T}$ calculates work for blockchain PoW systems.
- Proof-of-Work calculation accuracy requires retaining many block headers as 'S'.
- PoPoW schemes adjust header storage based on blockchain height, ensuring scalability.

recent_posts.title: Krux: KEF Encryption Format
recent_posts.summary:
- The Project Krux team announced advancements in encrypting bip39 mnemonics with KEF.
- KEF now supports variable-length strings and multiple AES modes, enhancing utility and user freedom.
- Community feedback is sought for KEF specification refinements, emphasizing backward compatibility.

recent_posts.title: Writing Simplicity Programs with SimplicityHL
recent_posts.summary:
- The discussion introduces a novel approach in SimplicityHL programming using custom sighash.
- It presents the concept of deferring program commitment decisions to signing time via delegation.
- Despite its theoretical viability, this adaptable sighash approach remains unimplemented in practice.

active_posts.title: [BIP Proposal] Utreexo Nodes
active_posts.summary:
- Dryja, Souza, and Kim propose three Bitcoin Improvement Proposals focusing on Utreexo.
- Utreexo allows verifying Bitcoin transactions without the full UTXO set, enhancing blockchain efficiency.
- The proposals aim for community feedback on GitHub to refine the Utreexo-focused BIPs.

active_posts.title: Taproot is post-quantum secure when restricted to script-path spends
active_posts.summary:
- A study reveals Bitcoin's Taproot security against quantum attacks, using the quantum random oracle model.
- It proposes a two-phase softfork for Bitcoin to ensure post-quantum security, justifying script-path spending's safety.
- Despite quantum threats, the current focus should be on classical computing's potential to compromise Taproot's security.

active_posts.title: Feedbacks on libbitcoinkernel & bitcoin backbone
active_posts.summary:
- Antoine has developed a multi-process, Rust-based Bitcoin node utilizing libbitcoinkernel 27.0.
- The project, still in demo phase, supports ARM and x86_64 platforms and simplifies the build toolchain.
- Challenges like transaction relay in multi-process setups are being addressed with innovative solutions.

active_posts.title: Stats on compact block reconstructions
active_posts.summary:
- Compact block reconstructions in Bitcoin are analyzed for efficiency and transaction awareness.
- Adjustments in node configurations and network congestion impact block reconstruction rates.
- Further research could optimize block reconstructions, considering transaction requests and node types.

active_posts.title: A simple backup scheme for wallet accounts
active_posts.summary:
- Josh's method includes unique inscription and location features.
- The suggestion is to standardize Salvatore's method, then add Josh's aspects.
- This approach aims to merge both methods for a comprehensive solution.

active_posts.title: Exploring Extended Relative Timelocks
active_posts.summary:
- Discussions on extending Bitcoin's timelock to ~10 years explore significant protocol adjustments.
- A proposed method suggests using bit 21 in `nSequence` to signal longer timelocks, multiplying duration by 8.
- Experimentation includes a developed tool for creating compliant transactions, with feedback and alternatives considered.

today_in_history_posts.title: BIP proposal, Pay to Contract BIP43 Application
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- The pay-to-contract protocol utilizes elliptic curve encryption's homomorphic properties without standard guidelines.
- A trade finance application, compliant with BIP43, has been developed to establish transaction standards.
- This application's process involves defining BIP32 paths, hashing documents, and generating contract commitment addresses.

today_in_history_posts.title: BOLT 11, real time micro payments, and route redundancy
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Andy Schroder inquires about the absence of a refund address in BOLT 11.
- He discusses adapting a fuel pump for Lightning with the need for pre-payment refunds.
- Schroder explores real-time micropayments for vehicles and suggests improvements for reliability.

today_in_history_posts.title: Deflationary money is a Good Thing
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Investment strategies include passive (buy-and-hold assets) and active (hands-on management).
- Passive investments can cause societal issues, such as asset value misalignment and underutilization.
- The article discusses using Bitcoin for an inflationary/deflationary currency system to stabilize economies.
